docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton, giving his weekly radio address a Mother's Day theme, endorsed legislation that would require health plans to cover at least 48 hours of hospital care after a baby was born. The legislation is unpopular with health maintenance organizations, which are wary of any steps that would allow the Federal Government to dictate coverage. The President complained that "a large and growing number of insurance companies are refusing to pay for anything more than a 24-hour stay, except in the most extreme circumstances."

headline.main: Clinton Endorses Bill On Childbirth Care

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It was sad to read that former Mayor John V. Lindsay, in declining health, was without adequate health insurance (news article, May 3). While I concur that a former leader of New York City should not be without a pension or health care, I do not agree with the method Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani selected to provide him with municipal health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just weeks after Ross Perot's unsuccessful run for the White House in 1992, he started what he touted as a citizen-financed, nonpartisan truth squad that would transform the way in which Washington does the people's business. But today, as Mr. Perot tries to put a third party on the 1996 Presidential ballot and ponders a second run for the Oval Office, what he envisioned as a source of feedback and advice that politicians could not afford to ignore is only a skeleton of what he set out to build.

headline.main: Perot Group Falls Far Short Of Original Political Vision

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Increases 43 Points On Calming Inflation Report Capping one of the most volatile trading weeks in recent memory, stocks drove ahead as a benign wholesale inflation report calmed investors' nerves. Producer prices in April posted a smaller-than-expected rise of four-tenths of 1 percent. The Dow jumped 43 points, to 5,518.14. [Page 35.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Adding a new element of controversy at strike-torn Barnard College, administrators have told six seniors who participated in a four-hour sit-in last month that their diplomas would be withheld until disciplinary cases against them are resolved. The seniors, who joined the sit-in in support of a four-week strike by the college's clerical workers, contend that Barnard is being heavy-handed and insensitive in delaying their graduation over what they say was a peaceful act of conscience that caused minimal disruption.

headline.main: Barnard Delays Six Diplomas Over Sit-In

docs.lead_paragraph: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation will pay as much as $19 million to three top officers and an outside legal counsel of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio who engineered the insurer's pending sale to Columbia, Blue Cross disclosed today. Columbia, which is based here and is the nation's largest hospital operator, said in March that it would buy most operating units of the Blue Cross plan, a nonprofit mutual insurer, for $299.5 million. Terms of non-competition and consulting agreements were included in a filing with the Ohio Department of Insurance in Columbus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George Pataki has forged a valuable agreement among rival groups of doctors, consumers, health maintenance organizations and employers on consumer protections for the six million New York State residents in managed-care health plans. His proposed bill, the result of months of arduous negotiations, would insure that an anxious public gets the information it needs to make smart choices on health coverage. At the same time, the Governor resisted lobbying by physician and other groups for provisions that could have hobbled managed care. The Governor's bill would require health plans to provide their members information about the plans' rosters of doctors and hospitals, access to specialists and the process for authorizing treatment. The bill would require plans to set up standardized grievance and appeals procedures for individuals who feel they were unjustly denied coverage. It would prohibit "gag" rules that restrict physicians from advising patients about treatments the plan might not cover, and require coverage for reasonable use of hospital emergency rooms.

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Bobbitt Sr. is a past president of the board of the Canton Urban League. For much of his life, civil rights have been the most important political issue for Mr. Bobbitt, who is black. Even as he moved upward in the corporate world, becoming a vice president for Pepsi-Cola in Detroit, he continued to vote for the party he felt was best for him and for black people, the Democrats.

headline.main: Minimum Wage? As One Man Finds, It's Really a Matter of Perspective

docs.lead_paragraph: This year, Harvey Gantt said today, will be different. After winning an impressive victory in North Carolina's Democratic Senate primary on Tuesday, Mr. Gantt began making the case today that he is a different candidate and that this is a different state than in 1990, when he lost his first race to Senator Jesse Helms.

headline.main: Rival Vows to Give Helms a Tougher Battle
